cards.name: Western Harvest Mouse
cards.flavorText: Weighing under 15 grams, it builds spherical grass nests and can produce up to 10 litters per year.

cards.name: Arctic Ground Squirrels
cards.flavorText: The only mammal that can supercool its body below freezing — brain temperature drops to -3°C during hibernation.

cards.name: Snowshoe Hare
cards.flavorText: Its oversized hind feet act like snowshoes, and its coat turns white in winter — a full molt every season.

cards.name: Bobcat
cards.flavorText: A solitary ambush hunter that can take down prey up to 8x its weight, including deer and small livestock.

cards.name: Florida White Rabbit
cards.flavorText: Domestic rabbits can conceive again within hours of giving birth — a 30-day gestation fuels explosive population growth.

cards.name: Giant Golden Mole
cards.flavorText: Completely blind and earless, it 'swims' through Namib Desert sand using powerful forelimbs to detect vibrations from prey.

cards.name: Japanese Weasel
cards.flavorText: Has anal scent glands that spray a foul musk when threatened. It can kill rats, frogs, and snakes twice its size.

cards.name: Meerkat Matriarch
cards.flavorText: The dominant female produces 80% of the mob's pups and can kill subordinates' offspring to maintain control.

cards.name: North American Opossum
cards.flavorText: Its 'playing dead' is involuntary — a catatonic state lasting up to 4 hours, complete with drool and foul odor.

cards.name: Black Tree-kangaroo
cards.flavorText: One of the few kangaroo species adapted to trees — it can leap 30 feet down to the forest floor unharmed.

cards.name: Platypus
cards.flavorText: One of five egg-laying mammals. Males have venomous ankle spurs that deliver excruciating, morphine-resistant pain.

cards.name: Red-handed Howler
cards.flavorText: Its howl reaches 140 decibels — audible 3 miles away — thanks to an enlarged hyoid bone that acts as a resonator.

cards.name: Sable
cards.flavorText: Its fur was once worth more than gold by weight. Sables are one of few mustelids that breed only once per year.

cards.name: Pronghorn
cards.flavorText: Sustains 55 mph over long distances — evolved alongside now-extinct American cheetahs, explaining its extreme speed.

cards.name: Golden Takin
cards.flavorText: Secretes an oily substance that waterproofs its coat in Himalayan rains. Herds live above 4,000 meters elevation.

cards.name: Black Springbok
cards.flavorText: Performs 'pronking' — leaping 6 feet straight up — likely to signal fitness to predators and deter pursuit.

cards.name: Holstein Friesian
cards.flavorText: The world's highest-producing dairy breed, averaging 23,000 lbs of milk per year — over 2,600 gallons annually.

cards.name: Hart
cards.flavorText: A mature male red deer. It regrows its antlers annually — up to an inch per day, the fastest bone growth in any mammal.

params.title: Choose a carrion to add to hand

cards.name: Malayan Tapir
cards.flavorText: A key seed disperser — its dung germinates forest plants. Calves are born with stripes that fade to black and white.

cards.name: Mountain Zebra
cards.flavorText: Adapted to steep, rocky terrain above 2,000 meters. Its stripe pattern is species-unique — narrow with a white belly.

cards.name: Mountain Reindeer
cards.flavorText: The only deer species where both sexes grow antlers. Their eyes shift to UV vision in winter to spot lichen on snow.

cards.name: Muskox
cards.flavorText: Its qiviut undercoat is 8x warmer than sheep wool by weight. Herds form defensive circles against wolves, calves inside.

cards.name: Giant Forest Hog
cards.flavorText: The largest wild pig — up to 600 lbs. Only discovered by science in 1904 despite living in African forests for millennia.

cards.name: Alaskan Moose
cards.flavorText: The largest deer species — bulls exceed 1,500 lbs with 6-foot antler spans. They can dive 18 feet to eat aquatic plants.

cards.name: Dholes
cards.flavorText: Asian wild dogs that communicate with whistles instead of howls. Packs of 12+ can drive tigers off their kills.

cards.name: Eurasian Lynx
cards.flavorText: Europe's third-largest predator. Its tufted ears improve hearing by 20%, and it can detect a hare at 300 meters.

cards.name: Gray Wolf
cards.flavorText: Packs maintain territories of 80-300 square miles. Their reintroduction to Yellowstone literally changed river courses.

cards.name: Black Leopards
cards.flavorText: Melanism occurs in about 11% of leopards. Their rosette markings are still visible under infrared light.

cards.name: Jaguar
cards.flavorText: Has the strongest bite relative to size of any big cat — powerful enough to pierce turtle shells and caiman skulls.

cards.name: North American Cougar
cards.flavorText: Holds the record for the largest range of any wild land mammal in the Americas — from Yukon to Patagonia.

cards.name: Malayan Tiger
cards.flavorText: Fewer than 150 remain in the wild, making it the most endangered tiger subspecies. It hunts sun bears and tapirs.

cards.name: Southern African Lion
cards.flavorText: A lion's roar reaches 114 decibels, audible 5 miles away. Females do 90% of the hunting; males defend territory.

cards.name: Sumatran Tiger
cards.flavorText: The smallest surviving tiger — about half the size of a Bengal. It has webbed toes for swimming through Sumatran swamps.

params.title: Choose a carrion to copy abilities from

cards.name: Cheetah
cards.flavorText: Reaches 70 mph in 3 seconds but overheats after 30 seconds. It succeeds in only 40-50% of hunts.

cards.name: Grizzly Bear
cards.flavorText: Emerges from hibernation having lost up to a third of its body weight. It can eat 90 lbs of food per day in autumn.

cards.name: Kodiak Bear
cards.flavorText: The largest brown bear subspecies — males exceed 1,500 lbs. Isolated on Kodiak Island for 12,000 years.

cards.name: Polar Bear
cards.flavorText: Its fur is transparent, not white — each hollow hair scatters light. Its skin underneath is jet black to absorb heat.

cards.name: Hippopotamus
cards.flavorText: Kills more humans in Africa than any other large animal. It secretes natural red sunscreen and can outrun most people.

cards.name: Blizzard
cards.flavorText: Mammals survive blizzards via brown fat thermogenesis — burning specialized fat cells to generate heat without shivering.

cards.name: Milk
cards.flavorText: Mammary glands define the class Mammalia. Milk composition varies wildly — hooded seal milk is 60% fat.

cards.name: Rifle
cards.flavorText: Firearms drove 2% of mammal species to extinction since 1500. Humans are the only mammal to hunt at global scale.

cards.name: Six-layered Neocortex
cards.flavorText: Unique to mammals, this brain structure handles reasoning and language. In humans it contains 16 billion neurons.

cards.name: White Hart
cards.flavorText: White deer lack camouflage yet survive — many cultures historically forbade hunting them, creating accidental refuges.

cards.name: Curiosity
cards.flavorText: Neophilia — attraction to novelty — is a mammalian trait linked to dopamine. It drives exploration but increases predation risk.

cards.name: Tranquilizer
cards.flavorText: Modern tranquilizer darts use etorphine — 3,000x stronger than morphine — and can immobilize an elephant in 10 minutes.

cards.name: Warm Blood
cards.flavorText: Endothermy lets mammals stay active in any climate. Maintaining 37°C costs 10x more energy than cold-blooded life.

cards.name: Human Intervention
cards.flavorText: Wildlife management relocated 67 gray wolves to Yellowstone in 1995-96, triggering a trophic cascade across the ecosystem.

cards.name: Pitfall
cards.flavorText: Pitfall traps date back 45,000 years in mammoth hunting. Humans are the only mammal to engineer passive traps.

cards.name: Snow Squall
cards.flavorText: Sudden whiteout events drop visibility to zero. Arctic mammals survive by sensing magnetic fields to navigate blind.

cards.name: Burial Ground
cards.flavorText: Elephants revisit bones of dead relatives, gently touching them with their trunks — one of few mammals to mourn their dead.
